comment: Not enough seats in the outdoor area...couldn't sit outside the restaurant to eat and watch the planes take off...disappointing in this aspect

address: 20, Sec A #01-22 & 24, Sin Ming Industrial Estate Singapore 575678 Singapore
comment: Great location and views of Seletar tarmac. Nice ambiance. One thing from my wishlist: have something besides hef beer on tap. Little more parking won't hurt either. Food is a pretty decent mixture of ang mph and local. We definitely had fun.

address: 20, Sec A #01-22 & 24, Sin Ming Industrial Estate Singapore 575678 Singapore
comment: Was impressed with the ayam panguang, similar to ayam penyet. I find the chili sauce superb and not too strong. The view of airplanes right next to the restaurant is unique and interesting. Secluded place and well worth a visit and probably many returns.

address: 20, Sec A #01-22 & 24, Sin Ming Industrial Estate Singapore 575678 Singapore
comment: The whole Seletar area is bustling with new cafes and restaurants, and this cafe seems to be a nice addition to them. If you're looking for a quiet and relaxed night of afternoon just staring at planes taking off, this would be a good place. Had a flat white and their ondeh ondeh cake which was apparently the best seller. Good coffee and tea time snack. Doubt I would try their mains menu though which just looks like any typical western steak chicken etc dishes. This place should be ideal for just an afternoon get together or a night time session to enjoy a few beers with friends.

address: 20, Sec A #01-22 & 24, Sin Ming Industrial Estate Singapore 575678 Singapore
comment: Nice looking place by the airport, with indoor and outdoor dine in area. If one don't mind the noise, it was great sitting outdoor, looking at the planes taking off. Menu was a tab limited with a single page of food items and a single page of drinks.The place was beautifully decorated with bicycles hanging on the walls.

address: 20, Sec A #01-22 & 24, Sin Ming Industrial Estate Singapore 575678 Singapore
comment: If you are one of those (like me) who prefer to dine at far flung location away from the madding crowd, this would be the ideal place for you.Apart from Changi Airport, you cannot find another dining location where you could watch jets take off and land from your dining table. Unlike Changi, however, where the apron / tarmac separates you from the runway, you are only a stone's throw away from the runway at Soek Seng 1954 Bicycle Cafe (and those private jets' parking lots are literally right at the doorstep).The decor in this cafe is also interesting with more than 20 bicycles hanging around the cafe. These classic bicycles dating from the 50s belong to the owner and have all been restored to perfect working condition. Besides the bicycles, there are other bicycle related objects on display. Foodwise, the menu is a mixed-bag with some local fare and some western comfort food for lunch and dinner. There are a selection of cakes and coffee to complete your meal. Unfortunately, I don't think that food was their strongest point (doh!). It's ok for a casual meal, but nothing particular outstanding for me to remember. In summary, if you think that traveling to a remote part of Singapore for food is a chore or if you are looking for Michelin star quality, you may want to skip this cafe. If you want to come for a unique view away from the city and maddening crowd, you would have found your home.

address: Ang Mo Kio Avenue 8 Blk 709 Singapore 560709 Singapore
comment: After visiting this stall many times, I must say it is one of the best Japanese stalls in Singapore foodcourts I have ever seen. Not only does the stall offer a wide range of Japanese food, the prices are also at a generally acceptable level. My favourite dish here is curry beef set meal which costs S$6.30. The main components include pieces of teriyaki beef slices and a bowl of curry sauce for you to dip so as to enhance the flavour of beef. Very often the bowl of curry comes with one or two pieces of carrot as well. Other components in this set meal include a bowl of seaweed soup as well as 2 blocks of agedashi tofu. The seaweed soup is not only tasty but, visually appealing. I could even see particles dangling in the bowl of soup. While in other places agedashi tofu of the same quantity is generally sold at S$2, I feel it is worth the price here as this S$2 has been included in the total price of S$6.30. Besides, the agedashi tofu here tastes much better than other places. I enjoy the wonderful sensation when the skin of agedashi tofu melting in my mouth very much. I am not sure how it's cooked, but I have seen stalls elsewhere simply pour boiled water over a bowl of lightly fried agedashi tofu and eventually add some octopus flakes. No wonder they taste so differently. Given the scenario of the current global recession, enjoying quality and affordable Japanese cuisine at this place is undeniably a wise choice.

address: 721 Ang Mo Kio Ave 8 Singapore 560721 Singapore
comment: All over the signboard of Penang Delights is the review by channel U and it's acknowledgement of it's great prawn mee. While it does seem to be a decorated stall, do not let it's short queue question it's taste. That is because Penang Delights has a very fast service time, keeping the queue short and customers happy.Whenever I drop by Ang Mo Kio, this stall would be one of my prime considerations. I would order a large bowl of their prawn mee with added chili. The prawns were fresh and one could taste prawns in their prawn broth, showing the long hours put by the owner into watching the delicious pot of broth. While the texture of the noodles were average, it is compensated for by the presence of boiled pork strips to add to the chewiness in every mouthful. I find that it is customary to finish the broth despite it being more spicy than the average chili.Price wise, it is affordable, at $4.50 for a large bowl. One should definitely consider having Penang Prawn mee at this stall and realize how high a bar this stall has set for the standards of good prawn mee.

address: 422 Ang Mo Kio Ave 3 Singapore 560422 Singapore
comment: Have been visiting this place since 2015; the place I always go to for my beef burger comfort food fix during NS, manned by a single guy

address: 16 Jln Selaseh Singapore 808440 Singapore
comment: An unassuming restaurant in a residential suburb, modest size, the girl doesn't speak nor understand much English ... All sound cliche..... Until you get the food!!  The spicy tofu is amazingly fresh, spicy fish is very tasty with the sauce.  The duck is fantastic with a smoky flavor, and the little cabbage square in a thick sauce was succulent.All in all the place was a very pleasant surprise and an asset to the neighborhood.

address: 68 Serangoon Garden Way Singapore 555964 Singapore
comment: Surprisingly good poke bowl with generous toppings of onions, seaweed and fatty pork. It just tastes so good together!Their yakotoris are also very respectable. They have a wide selection of drinks and alcohol which you can come over as a yakitori time w friends over a beeer. The service is friendly generally. Tuesday nights they have ladies night - $10 free flow of drinks including alcohol. Pretty good deal.

address: 68 Serangoon Garden Way Singapore 555964 Singapore
comment: Quality of food at those pricing, definitely not worth. Tasteless for most items we ordered. Slow service. Ambience still alright but overall a place that I wouldn't make a return visit.

address: 68 Serangoon Garden Way Singapore 555964 Singapore
comment: This is a brand new Yakitori Bar in Serangoon Gardens there serves delicious Japanese cuisine together with a wide selection of sakes and alcohol. Nice ambience for friends and family and food is very tasty! Yakitori is freshly grilled on order and didn't take long to arrive. Loved the selection skewers and you can't go wrong with their 7 plus 1 yakitori dinner soecial! Give this place a try if you love Japanese cuisine. You will be pleasantly surprised!

address: 5 Ang Mo Kio Central 2 #01-06 Singapore 569663 Singapore
comment: The restaurant opened last year, taking over the space formerly occupied by a Korean BBQ restaurant. During lunch time, the thai restaurant offered lunch meal priced from $4.50+ onwards, with drinks at $2. There was 10% service charge but no GST.Thai Braised Pork Trotter Rice ($4.50+)The trotter was served cut up into slices and tasted quite flavourful and tender. Remember to add the spicy tangy chilli sauce to the meat which peak up the taste. The dish was served with braised egg, pickled mustard, green leafy vegetables and a bowl of garlicky soup. I like that the dish was served smoking hot. Iced Milk Tea (ala carte $3.90+)The drink was rich without too sweet.Overall the food was delicious and served fast.

address: 5 Ang Mo Kio Central 2 #01-06 Singapore 569663 Singapore
comment: This is probably one of the best Mookata that I have tasted.. the Thai milk tea is sweet and nice. Service is good and price is reasonable.

address: 5 Ang Mo Kio Central 2 #01-06 Singapore 569663 Singapore
comment: We ordered some drinks and ONLY mango sticky rice dessert. It took half an hour and the dessert is not out yet. We walked out. Horrible service.

address: 218 Sumang Walk Singapore 821217 Singapore
comment: Excellent Hokkien Mee. Not usually a fan of the gooey type but this stall makes it just right. Flagrant and smoky with nice sized prawns. Tried the carrot cake and it was superb too, not too salty. Hidden gem in Punggol!

address: 218 Sumang Walk Singapore 821217 Singapore
comment: Thanks to an article shared on social media recently, this place was made known. Hawker fares and great food are what Punggol residents have been yearning for for years. There is no centralized hawker centers but scattered coffee shops and food court all over made tracking good food difficult. However, this Hokkien is a pure delight to residents here. It is prepared by the distinct looking 70 year old uncle. Kudos to him because opening hours start from 11am to 11pm. He takes a break between 2-5pm. It's no easy feat, plus it's opened on most days of the week.This hokkien mee is sure not to be missed if you like the wetter version. This is really wet, stock is really flavorful and it really combines very well with the noodles. The wok hei (wok taste) is also very much apparent, yet not overpowering (which could make it tastes like chao tah (burned). Very light and comforting wok hei. That takes skills man!Chilli is the light orange kind of color. I'm not sure if they make their own chilli or get it from a supplier, but the chilli is well made, well blended to the noodles and has a kick. The lime, the chilli and the noodles are a very good combination. Queues can be long on the weekends and during lunch. Do try it after 7pm or for a supper. The let down is probably the food court's ventilation isn't very good and it can get pretty stuffy even in the night.

rest_name: Goki Day Korean BBQ Buffet Restaurant
address: 19 Teck Chye Terrace Singapore 545725 Singapore
comment: KBBQ-AYCE.Who wouldn't be down for that? Just pack your Febreeze, bring an extra shirt, a stack of wet wipes, and a carnivorous-YOLO-appetite...and you'll find yourself at home here. You'd even feel like some all-star chef grilling meat in Kitchen Stadium trying to compete against all the other tables to find out whose GRILLING REIGNS SUPREME.RIGHT.We arrived to find an almost-packed-established filled with people smoking up the whole place with the familiar scent of animal martyrs sizzling atop electric grills emanating a reddish light. We have entered...meat-lovers heaven. Our lil'team made quick work and shuffled out to the meat section and began piling everything we desired into several plates before busing it all back to our tiny table for 4. We barely had space left on our table to maneuver and started pouring as much as we could onto the grill. The meat selection consisted of the usual favorites - marinated beef (bulgogi and kalbi), beef brisket, prawns, hotdogs, imitation crab and meatballs, pork belly (spicy, herbal-thin-sliced, non-marinated), pork loin/cutlet, and chicken (marinated, spicy).The greens and extras include lettuce, sliced garlic, green chillies, pickled radishes (sliced), and some cooked food, such as sweet and sour pork, Korean pancakes, porridge, and seaweed-miso soup.VERDICT:Friendly staff and definitely a great KBBQ-AYCE spot...that actually beats some of the better LA spots that I have frequented in the past. I'll definitely be back again!PRICES:Tuesday-Friday Lunch - $15.90+Dinner & Weekends/Public Holidays - $24.90+**Early Dinner SPECIAL - arrive after 17:30 and leave by 19:00 and get 20% off your total bill.Yelp 100: 6/100

rest_name: Goki Day Korean BBQ Buffet Restaurant
address: 19 Teck Chye Terrace Singapore 545725 Singapore
comment: My Korean colleague always come to this place. The boss and waiters are Koreans too. I really enjoy BBQ here with friends.

address: 238 Thomson Road #02-46, Novena Square Singapore 307683 Singapore
comment: My husband and I definitely went through a Gyu Kaku phase a while back. We're definitely not made of money, but this Novena outlet isn't Prime, meaning it doesn't focus much on Wagyu beef and it's a lot more casual. This makes it one of the cheaper Gyu Kaku's on the island. We're set in our ways, so we always do 3 orders of the Harami (inner skirt steak) with just rock salt and no marinade, 3 orders of rice (husband must have copious amounts of rice or else he'll die), 1 order of mushrooms, 1 order of corn, 2 hot green teas, and 2 ice waters.I don't know what kind of witchcraft they do here, but the grills really are smokeless. I don't ever recall leaving and smelling like what I just ate.We also love the dipping sauces that comes with the meat, one of them is sweet, the other is supposedly spicy but I don't taste a hint of spiciness. We've never had a bad steak here, so we're happy that this outlet is near us. The service has always been pretty good; everyone smiles, water and tea are refilled often and they're good about checking whether or not your grill plate needs replacement. You'll be sure to find us here for a weeknight dinner or early weekend dinner! :)

address: 238 Thomson Road #02-46, Novena Square Singapore 307683 Singapore
comment: just three words: Miyazaki Japanese Wagyu.and in SG, it is only available at this gyu kaku outlet!!!so focus you must on this prime cut of beef from the miyazaki prefecture that is the second largest producer of japanese black cow.though not the top three in terms of recent ranking, this class of cow boasted the "Champion Cow" of the "Wagyu Olympics" in 2007.they are not quite your yakiniku yazawa in terms of quality but also not quite break the bank and be a bankrupt prices.yes, a reader of my yakiniku yazawa review recently commented that i should include prices in my reviews in the future! thanks for the feedback but that is not quite my style of writing and has never been the focus of my reviews?!anyways, i take that to mean he was shocked and awed by yakiniku yazawa's prices?!but fear not when you dine here, even if you do decide to include wagyu in your dietary plans.no need to print money la, just don't eat it so often lor.hmmmmm i just might go there for lunch after writing this piece.in any case, this outlet offers way more than just miyazaki japanese wagyu.be it regular beef, tongue, seafood, chicken or pork, just choose the protein of your choice.they also cater to the vegetarian palate.as for the carbo addicts, their rice, udon and ramen will definitely satiate and fill you somewhat.but it is the delightful experience of a naked charcoal fire, without the smoky perfumery and the innate ability of their staff to see to it that you get a fresh grill as and when you need it, that i like.ok, ok, it is mainly the affordable miyazaki japanese wagyu that i'm lusting after!*insert GUILTY face*my first gyu kaku experience was in midtown east NYC, way back in 2007, so boy am i glad that there is one right here in my hood!i might not be a champion sumo wrestler but i definitely wouldn't mind being presented with one miyazaki cow!:)

address: 238 Thomson Road #02-46, Novena Square Singapore 307683 Singapore
comment: Finally. A decent Yakiniku restaurant has returned to Novena. In the 90s, there was Yakiniku DaiDoMon at Novena Ville (that was ala carte only). They closed and reopened at united square a few years ago. And finally closed in 2013, after struggling with intense competition and an identity crisis (buffet or premium jap Yakiniku?) Hmm. Same thing about Italian restaurants, Al Forno opened at Novena Ville, opened a larger restaurant at Goldhill and closed. And in 2013, a decent pizza arrived in Extra Virgin Pizza. Anyways. This is Gyu-Kaku's concept casual restaurant. You get a simplified menu (way less options). 6-7 types of beef cuts. Set meals for 2-3 pax. Ranging from $60 to $90 (for 2). Non beef options are there, pork, seafood, vege. Oh yes. There is Ox Tongue. Grilled. With a dash of lemon juice.Update: Prices seems to have dropped to go more mainstream. Now they have beef platters for $24, $41.

address: 238 Thomson Road #02-46, Novena Square Singapore 307683 Singapore
comment: Japanese BBQ place if you craving for some meat, a bit pricey but if you like Japan Wagyu Beef this is not a bad option.I spend average $40 / pax for ordering 3 kinds of beef. The serving of beef portion is small.

address: 238 Thomson Road #02-46, Novena Square Singapore 307683 Singapore
comment: Their lunch sets are reasonably priced and decent, but nothing to shout about.Their dinner BBQ options are decent, but are of course a little pricey (and there are better places for Japanese BBQ).

address: 6 Ang Mo Kio Street 53 Singapore 569205 Singapore
comment: Seriously this place has one of the best crispy and thick waffles I have ever eaten! When I placed my order, the waiter came to tell me it would take at least 15 minutes. I ordered a sour plum soda $3 + $1 for iced. It tasted good to me, my mother had expected it to be a bit sweeter.Rum and Raisin Waffles $9++When it was served to me, it looked so brown, I had wondered if it was burnt, but it didn't smell burnt. The ice cream tasted strong of alcohol, there were raisins in the ice cream and in almost every pocketed square of the waffle as well! The waffle was so crispy and because it was a very thick waffle, it was still fluffy on the inside. Even my mother compliment the waffle, and she rarely has great things to say about waffles, considering she made waffles for breakfast just yesterday.All in all, they serve a variety of food and I will be back to try more main course and definitely for more waffles!

address: 6 Ang Mo Kio Street 53 Singapore 569205 Singapore
comment: Sometimes it's really hard to find a nice place for dinner in the neighbourhood that has a good ambiance and also open till late. Bliss Restaurant may not serve the best food around, but it certainly has a nice chilling atmosphere for you to sit and enjoy a nice supper or late night drink with a good friend.I never knew the Community Centres can be so hip until I visited Bliss Restaurant at Cheng San CC. The food was so-so but the environment is pretty good. Besides the "hu" and the "hah" from the guys in the basketball court doing taekwando or other activities, it's actually pretty enjoyable. You can choose from the alfresco outdoor dinning (it can get rather dim so you may not really be able to see what you are eating) or the indoor dinning (for those who cannot live without aircon).They also have an interesting selection of alcohol from beer to wines and even cocktails. For some sweet bites, the selection of desserts is still decent but of course, not comparable to a town restaurant.The price is economical and overall experience. Wouldnt mind hanging out there again soon.

address: 6 Ang Mo Kio Street 53 Singapore 569205 Singapore
comment: Food was good, but they forgot to serve my drink.My milkshake came without spoon.Indoor and outdoor seating.

address: 6 Ang Mo Kio Street 53 Singapore 569205 Singapore
comment: The ambience looks great and the offerings are good. Beers and wines. Nice and cool to relax after a day of hard work. A social restaurant.I had the lamp shank and felt that it was overlooked as the meat was too soft. The sauce wasn't adding enough flavours to the dish. Only the mash potato which supposed to be the secondary item tasted great. This is a restaurant where it creates jobs for the special people. Therefore please support them whenever you are nearby. Might try other foods next time. Giving them another chance.

address: 6 Ang Mo Kio Street 53 Singapore 569205 Singapore
comment: Heard that the food was good so I came to try it, but left disappointed.Waffles were soggy, meat wasn't well seasoned and didn't taste like much inside.Food was expensive. No air-con. No free tap water and cash only.Seriously, restaurant prices for a hawker experience... don't bother.

address: 6 Ang Mo Kio Street 53 Singapore 569205 Singapore
comment: A new found place to have a glass or two beer. It is located in a community center near to Ang Mo Kio MRT. The restaurant offers quite a variety of alcohol drinks besides the usual western menu. Something special in a neighbourhood.What we like about the place is that it offers alcohol at a reasonable price and not crowded. The pace there is slow and you can enjoy the night sitting there. Another good thing is that it is easily accessible, out of safety concern. we can take public transport back after in take of alcohol.Never had the chance to try any main dish there. But from observation, serving are quite big but serving time is quite slow. We ordered fries to go along with the beer. Beer took some time to be serve and fries took even longer. It was serve after we are half through our beer. But what's the hurry when you are at a slow pace place. Totally acceptable

address: 6 Ang Mo Kio Street 53 Singapore 569205 Singapore
comment: We had our dinner here as I was recommended by my colleague of the wide varieties of food they serve. The food was ok. Not exceptionally different than any other restaurants like swensen's. One thing to note, servers were inexperience and you could be exasperated that they kept coming to clear your dish when clearly food are still on the plates. They have their rubbish cart places right behind our seating area. I guess that explain why we have the fruitflies kept attacking our food. Some flies even fall into our plates. We were busy shooing the flies away while eating.We were there for long as a family gathering. When we left, 2 mins after we realized we left our daughter's jacket at the restaurant's chair. My husband walked back to retrieve it. To his astonishment, when he enquire with the waiter, clearly a senior waiter (maybe the business owner), the waiter mentioned that he threw the jacket away. My daughter's jacket is a sweet pink clean jacket wore only today! He could thought that it's unwanted and threw into their rubbish cart! It's totally bad service and even not wanting to keep the jacket thinking someone might come back to get it. To come for food to fill stomach and go, probably could consider. For service and food, McDonald's probably is a better place to eat.

address: 6 Ang Mo Kio Street 53 Singapore 569205 Singapore
comment: Bliss used to be at Punggol Park and it served the residents in the area very well. Waterfront dining by the pond was awesome. That's till it got taken over by Wild Oats. :( Nevertheless, we managed to hunt it down at Cheng San Community Center. It's quite a chill place if you stay on till late, which we did, with our bottle of Moscato. The drinks list is pretty extensive, like it was at Punggol Park. The service is more attentive now that the space is smaller and brighter (the servers can finally see our faces). Beer, cocktails, wines etc are available along with Western mains and snacks and desserts.We had some finger food which were not too bad. In my alcoholic state, i could hardly remember what i ate but i vaguely remember the cheese fries which were quite good and chicken wings maybe? The mud pie wasn't too shady as well.In all, not a bad place to get decent food and wine at affordable prices.

address: 6 Ang Mo Kio Street 53 Singapore 569205 Singapore
comment: Located within Cheng San Community Center, Bliss restaurant is an alfresco-themed restaurant serving western food. Their menu presents quite a standard selection of western food - grilled chicken, steak, pastas, fish.I ordered their grilled chicken and sausage, priced at $18.90 before GST. The presentation of the dish was pretty well done. However, the taste was normal: nothing good nor bad about the dish. After main course, my friends and I ordered some of their desserts: Choke on Choc and a Banana split. When it came, the portion was humongous. One can literally choke on the amount of ice cream served. We left the restaurant barely able to finish the desserts.I would say that their desserts were pretty good, but the main course meals were a bit on the expensive end, considering the quality of food. Service was slow, even for a a relatively empty restaurant. I recommend Bliss restaurant for some after meal desserts.

address: 6 Ang Mo Kio Street 53 Singapore 569205 Singapore
comment: As part of a large Community Club, Bliss Restaurant is hard to miss. With both an air-conditioned interior and an open-air exterior complete with candles perfect for chilling out with a drink alone or with friends, Bliss can accomodate a huge crowd. The food offered is reasonably tasty, with standard western fare like pasta and meat dishes. Their finger food stands out as awesome tidbits to share with friends and family. However, the selection of alcohol Bliss Restaurant offers makes one almost spoilt for choice. Picking your poison and pairing it with the proper dishes elevates the flavours and amplifies the experience.

address: 9 Bishan Place #02-19/20/27, Junction 8 Mall Singapore 579837 Singapore
comment: This is one of our favorite places for weekday dinner when we feel a little stressed out and want to skip the neighborhood zhu char or mixed rice place. The staff works at a high pace to get orders fulfilled and still have time to tend to minor details. We like the menu which is made to look like a newspaper and absolutely loved the food. The chicken and pastas are must tries.Mushroom soup and pumpkin soups are awesome.

address: 9 Bishan Place #02-19/20/27, Junction 8 Mall Singapore 579837 Singapore
comment: Looking for a fuss free place to have a quick dinner one day, a friend and I settled on Ambush, a cosy looking place occupying unique corner spot on Level 2 in Junction 8, connecting two separate wings of the mall. It's menu boasts the tastes of Europe, and of course realising that this was no fine dining establishment, we weren't expecting gastronomic adventures like never before, neither were we expecting bland attempts at being European in cuisine. We went in expecting the meal to be decently priced and of a decent quality suited for families, students, friends, and young couples alike from the neighbourhood and its surrounding towns.Being short on time we quickly started with the mini sausage platter, approximately $9, which we soon found to be one of the better items we savoured that night. Might I add that the waiters were pleasant, attentive, quick and were men of few words but without being rude. This was perhaps an advantage of our late arrival. The peak dinner time crowds could have left the waiters in a different mood altogether. Both the chicken garlic and chicken cheese sausages were tasty, juicy and filling. Enough to be an appetiser, yet leaving you with enough capacity to pursue a main course.We moved on to get the Zamorana Paella (Beaf meatball ham, sliced garlic chicken sausages and bacon - $13.50) as well as the braised lamb shank (with mashed potato and garden greens - $19.50) to share and we were left with mixed feelings at the end of the night. Having been to Spain I've come to realise that unless you're willing to pay top dollar, paella will never ever quite compare. But I enjoyed this dish, it was moist and tasty, with sufficient meat to satisfy my temporary paella craving. The lamb however, was disappointing. I felt it was a tad bit too raw, and perhaps the meat was not fresh and there was no rich flavour to the dish. I would skip the lamb shank on my next visit.There are many other dishes here to try, definitely heading back there on another occassion where a fuss free meal is warranted, however, I'd probably stick to the more safer and simpler looking dishes simply because I trust they would get it right like they did with the sausages. To be fair based on my first experience there, I am giving them a 3 star rating because I feel that they have yet to wow me.
